text: The cell mass breaks open to release hundreds of progeny cells.
For example, some cyanobacteria form cell aggregates that divide by multiple fissions, releasing dozens of daughter cells.
The unlimited growth of any population obeys a simple law: The growth rate, or rate of increase in cell numbers or biomass, is proportional to the population size at a given time.

If each cell produces two cells per generation, then the population size at any given time is proportional to 2n, where the exponent n represents the number of generations (that is, cell divisions in which offspring replace parents) that have taken place between two time points.
Such a growth rate is called “exponential” because it generates an exponential curve, a curve whose slope increases continually.
The process of reproduction has implications for growth not only of the individual, but also of populations.
Many microbes, however, have replication cycles based on numbers other than 2.
The cyanobacterium enlarges without dividing, and then suddenly divides many times without separating.
How does binary fission of cells generate an exponential curve?
If we assume that growth is unbounded, what happens to the population?
